title: 11 easy immune boosters for cold and flu season | CNN
author: Elizabeth Kuster; Upwave Com
description: Sick and tired of getting sick and tired every time a cold or flu bug rolls through your world? Want to improve your well-being and maybe even live longer?

Story highlights Singing and laughing have been shown to boost immunity Probiotics and prebiotics can also play a role Massage, meditation and sleep can be techniques to try Sick and tired of getting sick and tired every time a cold or flu bug rolls through your world? Want to improve your well-being, have more energy and maybe even live longer? Start working some of these fun (and simple!) immune boosters into your regular schedule, and you may be able to ward off illness better in the future. Here's looking achoo, immune system! [upwave: Take the challenge - Boost your immunity!](http://upwave.com/challenges/boost-your-immunity?cid=uwcnn01a) 1. Singing Research shows that [singing](http://www.heartresearch.org.uk/hearthealth/singinggood) is an [effective immunity booster](http://www.abc.net.au/news/2004-01-19/scientists-say-singing-boosts-immune-system/121668) - even if you're off-key. So sing in the shower in the morning. Sing in the car during your commute. Sing at home when you're doing the dinner dishes. But don't sing at work. That would be weird. (Just sayin'.) 2. Laughing According to a variety of studies, laughter [activates protective T-cells](http://www.webmd.com/balance/features/give-your-body-boost-with-laughter) and [ increases antibody production](http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/04/100426113058.htm). So listen to a hilarious podcast or shock-jock while you get ready for work. Watch an episode of your favorite sitcom while you eat breakfast. Watch a stand-up DVD during dinner. Crack open a funny book before you hit the hay. The more you LOL on a daily basis, the more you help your immune system stay strong. (And the nice thing about laughter is, it's often contagious. So you can spread the healthy benefits to others!) [upwave: Does laughing really help your health?](http://upwave.com/happiness/laughter-as-medicine-does-it-work?cid=uwcnn01a) 3. Stress-busters Stress is Public Enemy No. 1 when it comes to your immune system (the cortisol it produces [suppresses your immune cells](http://www.scq.ubc.ca/stress-cortisol-and-the-immune-system-what-makes-us-get-sick/)), so anything that lowers your stress levels will help your immune system do its job. Identify the people and activities that calm you down and take you to your happy place, then start fitting 'em into your schedule on a regular basis. 4. Probiotics The health of the GI tract plays a big role in bolstering the immune system. In fact, Amanda Bontempo, a registered dietitian at NYC's Montefiore-Einstein Center for Cancer Care, told upwave that " [the health of the GI system determines the health of the immune system.](http://upwave.com/wellness/how-to-boost-your-immune-system)" A major key to digestive health? Probiotics [such as yogurt, kefir, sauerkraut, miso all of which contain so-called " [good bacteria](http://upwave.com/workout/flat-stomach-without-stomach-exercises)" that helps your GI tract do its thang. [upwave: 7 ways to lighten up with Greek yogurt](http://upwave.com/weight-loss/greek-yogurt-recipe-substitutions?cid=uwcnn01a) 5. Prebiotics These soluble fibers - which are found in foods such as [bananas, artichokes, onions and leeks](http://www.prevention.com/food/healthy-eating-tips/how-probiotics-and-prebiotics-can-help-your-health/6-eat-prebiotics) - help probiotics work their magic, and therefore help the GI tract, too. 6. Human touch Getting a massage, hugging, holding hands, having sex - all [lower the body's immunity-weakening cortisol levels](http://www.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/01/05/touching.makes.you.healthier.health/index.html). According to research, getting a 45-minute massage also bolsters pathogen-fighting white blood cells and reduces inflammatory cytokines, which have been [connected to autoimmune diseases](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8707483). Having sex, hugging and holding hands cause our bodies to release cortisol-lowering oxytocin, making them awesome immune-system improvers. Some experts, in fact, recommend [eight hugs a day](http://upwave.com/family/how-to-hug) to take your oxytocin benefits to the max. So get your hug on! [upwave: 6 ways sex makes you healthy](http://upwave.com/sex/health-benefits-of-sex?cid=uwcnn01a) 7. Meditation Mindfulness meditation positively influences the immune system; according to one study, participants who meditated for eight weeks showed an [increased immune response to the flu shot](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12883106). If you're a morning person, start your day with a three-minute meditation session. Not an early bird? Meditate for three minutes when you get home from work, or when you're getting ready for bed. Meditation newbie? [Click here to learn how to do it](http://upwave.com/meditation/guided-meditation-in-3-minutes), courtesy of upwave review-board member Terri Cole. 8. Solid shut-eye Studies have found that sleep deprivation [lowers your T-cell count](http://upwave.com/wellness/how-to-boost-your-immune-system), thereby reducing your body's ability to fight off disease-causing pathogens. If you don't get eight hours of sleep on a regular basis, start taking steps to improve your sleep hygiene now. For tips (which include making 2 p.m. your last call for caffeine), check out our [Start A Healthy Sleep Routine Challenge](http://upwave.com/challenges/start-a-healthy-sleep-routine). 9. Moderate exercise Exercise doesn't just help your body fight infection: Research shows that it also [decreases your risk of getting diseases such as osteoporosis and cancer](http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/007165.htm). Even taking a 20-minute walk every day will strengthen your body's disease-fighting capabilities - 10 minutes out, and 10 minutes back. That's it! 10. Human connection According to research published by the American Psychological Association, [social isolation weakens immunity](http://www.apa.org/research/action/immune.aspx) and compromises the body's ability to fight infection. Social ties such as marriage, on the other hand, strengthen it. Feeling lonely? Seek the company of others - it will [strengthen your immune functioning](http://psychology.uchicago.edu/people/faculty/cacioppo/jtcreprints/ch09.pdf). 11. Greens Green veggies like bok choy, kale and broccoli give your immune system a leg up by ensuring that [immune cells in your gut are functioning properly](http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/10/111013121509.htm).
